title: Originally foreigners were not allowed to own land in the US, when did that change and why.? - Quora
tags: History of the United States of America
Politics of the United States of America

response.answer_text: I doubt that this is true. I am unaware of any US law that was ever in force that forbade foreigners as an entire class from owning land in the US. There were a number of laws passed in SOME states that forbade specific nationalities/ethnic groups from owning land, but this was NOT “original” as in from the founding of the US, and the Federal Government NEVER had such a law. California Alien Land Law of 1913 - Wikipedia

I know of no period in the US’s history when “foreigners were not allowed to own land” in the US. In fact, “foreigners” who had declared their intent to become citizens (but who had not done so) were free to homestead inexpensive land as far back as the law of 1862. Even though they were still “foreigners.” I have seen some pre-Civil War land records, and it appears that at least in some locations, new arrivals who had the resources were able to purchase residences, agricultural land, etc. as far back as the 1830’s. I’d be interested to know about any exceptions to this — do you have a citation?
